title: 114_hr4143
content:
The Act titled "Terrorist Refugee Infiltration Prevention Act of 2015" defines key terms. The Act titled "Terrorist Refugee Infiltration Prevention Act of 2015" defines key terms such as "country containing terrorist-controlled territory," "refugee," "substantial assistance," and "victim of genocide." The Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide was opened for signature in Paris on December 9, 1948. Prohibition on refugees from terrorist-controlled territories. Prohibition on refugees from terrorist-controlled territories under section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. An alien may not be admitted if they are a national of, habitually resided in, or claiming refugee status due to events in a country with terrorist-controlled territory. Exceptions exist if the alien proves they meet refugee admission requirements and are part of a designated group by the Secretary of State or Congress. An alien may not be admitted under paragraph (1) unless they have undergone the highest level of security screening, including biometrics and assessments by various government departments. Aliens seeking admission under section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act must be certified by the Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Director of National Intelligence if they provided substantial assistance to the United States and face a risk of harm if not admitted. SEC. 4. RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE. The Secretary of State may designate countries with terrorist-controlled territory, in addition to those listed in section 2(1)(A). The Secretary must maintain and update a list of these countries and make it available on various platforms. The Secretary of State is required to identify and update a list of groups considered victims of genocide, making it available to various entities including Congress and the public. Additionally, the Secretary may refuse to designate a group as an exception if it poses a significant security threat to the United States. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY.

The Secretary of Homeland Security must issue regulations to implement section 3 promptly. They are not allowed to admit any alien into the United States solely based on the alien's assertions. The Secretary must coordinate with other key agencies to verify the claims made by aliens seeking entry.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE PERIOD.

This Act will be effective for a 3-year period starting from the date of its enactment.
